title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Craigmillar Casing occupies a noble site on a wooded eminence two and a half miles to the south of Edinburgh. It is approached most easily by a narrow road which strikes off to the left hand at the village of Little France, two miles and a quarter on the old Dalkeith road. The rampart wall which surrounds the castle appears, from a date preserved on it, to have been built in 1427.

title: Secretar. Founded on the story of the Casket Letters
author: Beatty, W.
snippet: Dalkeith!" she snorted, eeing me with some contempt, doubtless taking me for a greater gawky than I was. " Dalkeith ! thisis no Dalkeith, but Little France as I tell'd you. Dalkeith's agude three mile further alang the road."

title: Secretar. Founded on the story of the Casket Letters
author: Beatty, W.
snippet: " There's nane that I wot o' : it's Little France ye're in," saidshe. " Maybe ye've heard tell o't ? "

title: Secretar. Founded on the story of the Casket Letters
author: Beatty, W.
snippet: " Little France," said I. " Nay, I never heard the name before." But yet, as I answered her, the thing had a familiar ringabout it that puzzled me.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: James V. occupied it occasionally during his minority, and in the eventful 1566, Queen IMary resided there, and held, with her deceitful and double-dealing counsellors, some of those dark and mysterious interviews which terminated in Darnley's death and her own ruin. From her residence here, the adjacent village acquired the name of Little France, her French guards being quartered there.

title: The Dead Beat
author: Johnstone, Doug
snippet: Martha didn't get off the bus at the Bridges, she was deliberately two hours early. Instead, she headed all the way south to Little France, to the ERI.

title: Secretar. Founded on the story of the Casket Letters
author: Beatty, W.
snippet: " Little France ! " I exclaimed, for I could not call to mindthat I had ever heard the name, whilk was not to be marvelledat, seeing I had never been that gate before, nor, indeed, a bowshot, as it were, from the Capital.

title: Secretar. Founded on the story of the Casket Letters
author: Beatty, W.
snippet: Some-deal disturbed, as much by his manner as by his speech,I held my peace until he had tended his beast, and we weregotten out into the garden ; but once there, and safe fromeavesdroppers, Gregory and I unloosed our tongues, and weresoon possessed of one anothers' doings since our last beingthegether. Gregory, I learned it was and no other that I hadseen that night I lodged in the house at Little France. By gudehap, it seems, he had been discovered by John Ballon, an auldcompanion in arms, and a retainer of Morton's, by whose aid hehad been transported to the biggin.
